questions.text: A 45-year-old male farmer presents to the clinic with intermittent fever, night sweats, and malaise that have persisted for several years. He has a history of drinking unpasteurized milk and assisting with livestock births. After extensive workup, he has been diagnosed with chronic brucellosis. The patient is concerned about the risk to his family and asks about tests that could be used to monitor the disease in himself and potentially in his family members who have similar exposures. Which of the following serological tests is least useful for monitoring chronic brucellosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coombs' Test

 

Option D:

 

The Coombs' test, also known as the antiglobulin test, is used to detect antibodies that act against the surface of the patient's own red blood cells, which is useful in diagnosing conditions like autoimmune hemolytic anemia, not brucellosis. 

 

Laboratory Diagnosis of brucellosis 

 

  1. Culture and Identification
     
  •  Sample: Blood, bone marrow, CSF, joint fluid or other tissues.
  •  Cultural media: Biphasic blood culture bottles media (Castaneda’s) made up of Brain heart infusion (BHI) broth/agar , Erythritol: Improves growth
  •  Automated techniques such as BACTEC and BacT/Alert systems.
  • Antibody Detection by Standard Agglutination Test (SAT) - the gold standard serological test. SAT detects IgM antibodies against antigens of smooth LPS: Hence useful for acute brucellosis
     
  1. Other Tests
     
  •  Serological tests to detect IgG antibody—2ME (2- mercaptoethanol) test, CFT, ELISA.
  •  PCR using primers for rrs-rrl gene, Omp2 gene and IS711 insertion sequence.
  •  Brucellin skin test
  •  Guinea pig inoculation
  •  Tbilisi phage typing is done
     
  1. Diagnosis of brucellosis in animals
     
  •  Isolation of brucellae from milk and dairy products.
  •  Antibody detection in milk: By Milk ring test, Rose Bengal card test, and whey agglutination test.
     

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Standard Agglutination Test (SAT) is used for the diagnosis and monitoring of brucellosis as it detects antibodies against Brucella.

 

Option B. The 2-Mercaptoethanol (2-ME) Agglutination Test is a more specific test for brucellosis because 2-ME inactivates IgM, allowing for the detection of the more specific IgG antibodies.

 

Option C. Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) can be used to detect specific antibodies against Brucella antigens and is useful in the diagnosis and monitoring of brucellosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brucellosis - The Coombs' test is irrelevant, while tests like SAT, 2-ME Agglutination Test, and ELISA are useful for diagnosis and monitoring. Antibody Detection by Standard Agglutination Test (SAT) is the gold standard serological test.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p359, 2/e p374, Ananthanarayan 9/e p343, 10/e p349

choices.text: Intramuscular penicillin G benzathine 2.4 million units weekly for three weeks
Intramuscular penicillin G benzathine 2.4 million units as a single dose
Intravenous penicillin G 3-4 million units every 4 hours for 14 days
Oral azithromycin 1g weekly for three weeks

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of unprotected sexual encounters presents with exertional dyspnea and chest pain. On examination, aortic regurgitation is noted. Serological tests return positive for syphilis. The patient is allergic to doxycycline. Considering the late cardiovascular manifestations of syphilis, what is the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intramuscular penicillin G benzathine 2.4 million units weekly for three weeks

 

This patient has late cardiovascular syphilis (aortic regurgitation due to syphilitic aortitis). The treatment of choice for late latent syphilis or tertiary syphilis (without neurosyphilis) is: Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly once weekly for 3 weeks. Even though he is allergic to doxycycline (which is an alternative), penicillin remains the drug of choice, and desensitization may be required if there is a severe allergy to penicillin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intramuscular penicillin G benzathine 2.4 million units as a single dose: This regimen is only for primary, secondary, and early latent syphilis (<1 year duration).

 

Option C. Intravenous penicillin G 3-4 million units every 4 hours for 14 days: This is the regimen for neurosyphilis (including ocular syphilis, tabes dorsalis, meningovascular syphilis). Not appropriate for isolated cardiovascular syphilis.

 

Option D. Oral azithromycin 1g weekly for three weeks: Azithromycin has been studied as an alternative for early syphilis, but resistance is common and it is not recommended in tertiary syphilis.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastryâ€™s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p394

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with a painless ulcer on his genitalia. He has no significant medical history and reports unprotected sexual contact. Physical examination reveals a clean base, non-exudative ulcer, and non-palpable inguinal lymph nodes. A darkfield microscopy examination of the ulcer exudate is performed. Which one of the following organisms, if seen under darkfield microscopy, would confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treponema pallidum

 

Option A:

 

Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, can be visualized using darkfield microscopy, which allows for the observation of live organisms and their characteristic motility. The presence of T. pallidum in ulcer exudate is diagnostic of syphilis, correlating with the clinical presentation of a painless genital ulcer, which is typical for primary syphilis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which presents as a painful ulcer and is not visualized on darkfield microscopy.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex virus causes painful genital ulcers and is diagnosed with Tzanck smear or PCR, not darkfield microscopy.

 

Option D. Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, presenting with beefy red ulcers and is diagnosed with Donovan bodies on tissue smear, not darkfield microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treponema pallidum can be visualized using darkfield microscopy. The presence of T. pallidum in genital ulcer exudate is diagnostic of syphilis. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1e/p372, 2/e p387

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with high fever, headache, and a rash that started on his trunk and spread peripherally. He recently returned from a camping trip. He is sexually active with one partner and uses condoms consistently. On examination, the rash spares his face and is notable for its centripetal spread. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rocky Mountain spotted fever

 

Option A:

 

Rocky Mountain spotted fever, caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, typically presents with fever, headache, and a centripetal rash that often involves the palms and soles. The patient's recent camping trip suggests a tick exposure, which is consistent with the epidemiology of this disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Secondary syphilis could present with similar symptoms but the rash of secondary syphilis also typically involves the palms and soles and is associated with sexual contact.

 

Option C. Lyme disease presents with erythema migrans, which is typically a single, expanding rash, not a centripetal rash.

 

Option D. Measles presents with a rash that spreads from the face downward and is preceded by cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis (the 3 Cs).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rocky Mountain spotted fever - Caused by Rickettsia rickettsii.

 

  • Transmission:  By the bite of an infected tick
  • Reservoir:  Ticks serve as vector as well as reservoir. Other mammals like dogs, small rodents can also act as reservoir
  • Clinical manifestations:  IP 4 to 14 days
    • An acute potentially fatal disease characterized by fever, headache, rash, myalgia and anorexia
    • Rashes appear typically on extremities (wrist and ankles) and trunk. Initially they are maculopapular, later become hemorrhagic

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p389, 2/e p404, Harrison 19/e p1155-59, 20/e p1304

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of several painless ulcers on her genitalia. She reports a new sexual partner 2 months ago but cannot provide his medical history. Physical examination reveals multiple, shallow ulcers with a non-purulent base on the labia majora and no inguinal lymphadenopathy. A darkfield examination of the ulcer exudate is planned. What organism, seen under darkfield microscopy (photo below), would be diagnostic in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treponema pallidum

 

Option A:

 

Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, can be identified by its characteristic morphology and motility using darkfield microscopy. The presence of painless genital ulcers is consistent with primary syphilis, and the identification of T. pallidum would confirm the diagnosis.

 

 

Figure: Direct microscopy of T. pallidum: A. Dark ground microscope; B. Direct fluorescent antibody staining for T. pallidum (DFA-TP); C. Silver impregnation method

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which presents with painful genital ulcers, not painless.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex virus causes painful vesicular or ulcerative lesions that can be diagnosed using PCR or viral culture.

 

Option D. Klebsiella  granulomatis is the cause of granuloma inguinale and would not be visualized using darkfield microscopy but rather identified by Donovan bodies on tissue smear.

 

Educational Objective

 

Primary syphilis is diagnosed by identifying Treponema pallidum in ulcer exudate using darkfield microscopy.

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan 9/e p372, 373, Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 4/e p759

choices.text: Fritz Schaudinn and Erich Hoffmann

questions.text: Who were the first scientists to identify the causative agent of syphilis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fritz Schaudinn and Erich Hoffmann

 

Option C:

 

Fritz Schaudinn and Erich Hoffmann first discovered Treponema pallidum, the spirochete bacterium responsible for syphilis, in 1905. This discovery was fundamental in understanding the pathogenesis and treatment of syphilis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Albert Neisser is known for the discovery of the causative agent of gonorrhea.

 

Option B. Robert Koch is renowned for his contributions to the germ theory of disease, notably identifying the causative agents of tuberculosis and cholera.

 

Option D. Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin, the first antibiotic, which is used to treat various bacterial infections including syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fritz Schaudinn and Erich Hoffmann - the first scientists to identify the b

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p5, 2/e p387, Ananthanarayan, 10/e p378-379

questions.text: In a case review session, a resident discusses a patient diagnosed with syphilis. The attending physician quizzes the resident on the diagnostic challenges of the disease. Which of the following clinical findings is least likely to aid in the isolation of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gumma

 

Option A:

 

Gummas are the characteristic lesions of tertiary syphilis and contain very few spirochetes, making them a poor choice for the isolation of Treponema pallidum. They are considered a late manifestation with a low bacterial load.

 

 

Figure: Gumma of nose due to long standing tertiary syphilis

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Primary chancre is rich in spirochetes and can be used to isolate the organism.

 

Option C. Mucosal patches in secondary syphilis also contain high numbers of spirochetes.

 

Option D. The maculopapular rash of secondary syphilis is another good source for organism isolation due to the high bacterial load.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gummas are the characteristic lesions of tertiary syphilis and contain very few spirochetes, making them a poor choice for the isolation of Treponema pallidum. 

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p374, 2/e p389, Ananthanarayan 9/e p372,, 10/e p380

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with a painless ulcer on his genitals. He is sexually active and has a history of unprotected intercourse. On physical examination, the ulcer is non-indurated and there is no regional lymphadenopathy. Darkfield microscopy is not available in your setting. Which of the following stains is most appropriate to visualize Treponema pallidum in the tissue sample from the ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fontana-Masson stain

 

Option D:

 

The Fontana-Masson stain is used to visualize spirochetes, including Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis. This stain is particularly useful when darkfield microscopy, the gold standard for direct visualization of Treponema pallidum, is not available. The stain works by depositing silver on the organism, which appears black against a yellow background.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Gram stain is used primarily for bacteria with cell walls and is not useful for visualizing spirochetes.

 

Option B. Acid-fast stain is used for mycobacteria and some other types of bacteria, but not for spirochetes.

 

Option C. Methenamine-silver stain is used for fungi and certain other organisms but is less specific for Treponema pallidum compared to the Fontana-Masson stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fontana-Masson stain is appropriate for visualizing Treponema pallidum, when darkfield microscopy (gold standard) is not available.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p376, 2/e p390, Ananthanarayan 9/e p372,, 10/e p381

choices.text: Desensitization to penicillin and then treatment with penicillin

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman at 8 weeks gestation, known to have an allergy to penicillin, presents with a positive Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test. Considering her pregnancy and penicillin allergy, what is the most appropriate management for syphilis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Desensitization to penicillin and then treatment with penicillin

 

Option C:

 

In a pregnant patient with syphilis and a penicillin allergy, the recommended approach is to desensitize the patient to penicillin and then proceed with penicillin treatment. Penicillin is the only antibiotic shown to be effective in preventing maternal transmission of syphilis to the fetus. Other antibiotics have not been proven to prevent congenital syphilis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Azithromycin is not recommended as first-line treatment for syphilis in pregnancy due to resistance issues and lack of evidence in preventing congenital syphilis.

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone can be considered in non-pregnant patients but is not the standard of care for preventing transmission to the fetus.

 

Option D. Doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy due to potential adverse effects on fetal development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Desensitization to penicillin followed by penicillin treatment is the recommended management for syphilis in a pregnant patient with penicillin allergy.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p379, 2/e p394, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1038, 20/e p1285

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a fever that has persisted for the past 4 weeks. The patient's temperature has been consistently above 101°F on multiple occasions. There is no known immunocompromised state, and a thorough history, physical examination, and obligatory investigations have failed to reach a diagnosis. What is the most likely classification of this patient's fever of unknown origin (FUO)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Classic FUO

 

Option A:

 

Classic FUO, as per the Durack and Street classification, is characterized by a fever > 101°F on multiple occasions, an illness duration of > 3 weeks, no known immunocompromised state, and a diagnosis that remains uncertain despite thorough evaluation. This patient meets the criteria for Classic FUO.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Nosocomial FUO - Nosocomial FUO occurs in hospitalized patients who develop a fever after being admitted to a healthcare facility.

 

Option C. Neutropenic FUO - Neutropenic FUO is seen in patients with neutropenia, typically due to chemotherapy, and is characterized by a fever in the absence of an elevated neutrophil count.

 

Option D. HIV-associated FUO - HIV-associated FUO occurs in patients with HIV infection who have a persistent fever that cannot be explained after evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic FUO is defined as a fever > 101°F on multiple occasions, an illness duration of > 3 weeks, no known immunocompromised state, and a diagnosis that remains uncertain despite thorough evaluation.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 4/e pg 299

choices.text: Genital ulcer diseases (Chancroid and chancre)
A combination of ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs (Chancroid, chancre, herpes genitalis)

questions.text: In the context of syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) in India, which group of symptoms is this approach most applicable for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A combination of ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs (Chancroid, chancre, herpes genitalis)

 

Option C:

 

Immediate syndrome-based treatment is recommended for the usual causes of acute genital ulcerations like syphilis,chancroid and herpes.

 

Syndromic management is designed to address the management of STIs based on the identification of consistent groups of symptoms and easily recognized signs, without laboratory tests. In India, this approach is applicable for a combination of both ulcerative and non-ulcerative STIs, which includes diseases like chancroid, syphilis (chancre), and herpes genitalis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Only includes two ulcerative STIs, not a combination of different types.

 

Option B. Discharge syndromes refer to different clinical presentations, typically characterized by discharge rather than ulcers.

 

Option D. Includes only ulcerative STIs but does not encompass the full scope of syndromic management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The principles of syndromic management in STIs, which involves treatment based on the identification of syndromes associated with STIs, such as ulcers and discharge, rather than specific etiological diagnosis.

 

Ref:   Harrison, 20/e p1285, 19/e p869-75

questions.text: A sexually active 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with a rash over his palms and soles, along with condylomata lata. Which stage of syphilis is the Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test most sensitive for in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary

 

Option B:

 

The VDRL test is most sensitive during the secondary stage of syphilis, where the bacterial load is highest. The presentation of rash on the palms and soles and condylomata lata is classic for secondary syphilis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The VDRL test is less sensitive in the primary stage compared to the secondary stage.

 

Option C. In the tertiary stage, the VDRL test is less sensitive due to the lower bacterial load.

 

Option D. Reactivation (or latent syphilis) may have low sensitivity on non-treponemal tests like VDRL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VDRL test is most sensitive during the secondary stage of syphilis, which often presents with systemic symptoms including rash and mucocutaneous lesions.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p377, 2/e p391-392, Ananthanarayan 9/e p375, 10/e p381

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with a history of untreated penile ulcer presents with new-onset ataxia and Argyll Robertson pupils. Which of the following tests is most appropriate for monitoring the patient's response to treatment for his neurosyphilis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VDRL

 

Option A:

 

The VDRL test, particularly when performed on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), is used to monitor the response to treatment in neurosyphilis due to its ability to quantify antibody levels, which should decrease with effective therapy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. FTA-ABS is a treponemal test used for confirmation of syphilis but not for monitoring response to treatment, as it remains positive for life.

 

Option C. TPI is a historical test not commonly used today.

 

Option D.  RPR is similar to VDRL and can be used for monitoring treatment response but is less specific than the VDRL when used on CSF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test is a non-treponemal serological test used to detect a patient's response to syphilis therapy, particularly neurosyphilis. Its titers usually correlate with disease activity and can decline following successful treatment, making it a useful tool for monitoring treatment response in neurosyphilis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p376-77, 2/e p391-392, Ananthanarayan 9/e p374-75, 10/e p381

choices.text: TPHA test on the serum sample of the mother
TPHA test on the serum sample of the infant
VDRL test on the paired serum samples of the infant and mother
Evaluating the time interval between the mother's treatment for syphilis and the delivery

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman with a reactive VDRL test delivers a baby. To assess the risk of congenital syphilis in the newborn, which of the following would be the LEAST helpful?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Evaluating the time interval between the mother's treatment for syphilis and the delivery

 

Option D:

 

The time interval between the mother's syphilis treatment and delivery is not a laboratory test and therefore does not directly help in assessing the newborn's risk for congenital syphilis. It is the context in which the other tests' results are interpreted rather than a diagnostic tool itself.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The TPHA test on the serum of the mother would confirm a past or present infection, which is crucial for understanding the potential for transmission.

 

Option B. A TPHA test on the serum of the infant is essential for diagnosing congenital syphilis, as it indicates an immune response from the infant itself.

 

Option C. A VDRL test on paired serum samples allows for comparison and assessment of the infant's antibody titers relative to the mother's, indicating the possibility of active infection in the newborn.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TPHA and VDRL tests on the infant are more direct and relevant in assessing the risk or presence of congenital syphilis.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p378, 2/e p393, Review article- Laboratory Diagnosis and Interpretation of Tests for Syphilis, CMR 1995/V8/no 1, Harrison, 20/e p1284; 19/e p1137

questions.text: A 5-year-old child in a rural tropical community presents with multiple painless skin ulcers and periostitis.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treponema pertenue

 

Option A:

 

Treponema pertenue is the causative agent of Yaws, a nonvenereal infection that primarily affects skin and bone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Treponema pallidum is the causative agent of syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection.

 

Option C. Treponema carateum causes Pinta, a skin disease that does not involve bone.

 

Option D. Haemophilus ducreyi causes Chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yaws, a treponemal infection caused by Treponema pertenue, which presents with painless skin ulcers and bone pain in children from tropical areas.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p394

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy living in a rural area of a tropical country presents to the clinic with a painless ulcer on his leg. He has had this ulcer for several weeks, and it has slowly increased in size. On examination, the ulcer is non-tender, with a raised edge and granulation tissue at the base. There are no other significant findings on examination. No history of sexual activity is reported. Which of the following treponemes is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treponema pertenue

 

Option A:

 

Treponema pertenue is the causative agent of Yaws, a chronic infection affecting primarily the skin, bones, and joints. It is prevalent in humid, tropical regions among children living in rural poverty. The clinical presentation described in the question - a painless ulcer on the leg of a child with no sexual activity history - is consistent with the early stage of Yaws. Yaws is not sexually transmitted, distinguishing it from syphilis, which is caused by Treponema pallidum.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Treponema carateum - Causes pinta, a skin disease characterized by depigmented lesions, not ulcers.

 

Option C. Treponema pallidum - Causes syphilis, which can present with a chancre, but is sexually transmitted and less likely in a child with no sexual activity.

 

Option D. Treponema cuniculi - Not a recognized human pathogen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yaws (Treponema pertenue) typically presents with a painless ulcer on the skin, especially in children living in rural, tropical areas. The disease is non-venereal and spreads through skin-to-skin contact.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p380, 2/e p394-395
